discussion.content: If it would state some servers I say B but now it looks like all servers and pentesting can cause disruptions. It's all in the wording
Rules of engagement pertains to the company who requested the scan so I don't see how C is correct. Should be B.

comments.content: On a second thought, C makes a lot of sense.

discussion.content: I think B is the answer. The reason why scope of work is included in the rules of engagement is for pen tester not to attack the truly critical servers in an org thereby distributing services being provided by that particular server.
Is this correct? I feel like B can also be a correct answer.

choices.C: To ensure all systems being scanned are owned by the company
choices.D: To ensure sensitive hosts are not scanned
choices.B: To ensure servers are not impacted and service is not degraded
choices.A: To ensure the network segment being tested has been properly secured

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes why it is important to include scope within the rules of engagement of a penetration test?

discussion.content: This is supposed to be C. Credit Card numbers and Personally Identifiable Information(PII)

comments.content: No it's not. It's PCI data.
CC is PCI. SSN would be PII

choices.A: Credit card numbers that are PCI
choices.B: Social security numbers that are PHI
choices.C: Credit card numbers that are PII
choices.D: Social security numbers that are PII

discussion.content: This is not a sV scan as there is no version output.... Correct answer is D.

comments.content: Wouldn't the answer still be "A"? Since the output is only listing port 80. With "D" your asking to list 'p ALL' indicating all ports. Even tho there wasn't a version being reflected A is still the best answer that meets what the question is asking?
-sP is the "no port" scan option, or "ping only" scan. It's used in host discovery. This is most definitely A.
There is a clue at the bottom saying "Service detection performed" so definitely A.
You are right, some people here are just confusing others who want to pass.

Always be patient to read through and pick out the give away clue...here is one "and is now scanning individual hosts to determine if any are running a web server"...the D you picked is not scanning individual hosts but ALL hosts...

Yes, but i'm still confused, as the question tells " .. if any are running a web server." 
as we know web servers goes on not only one port
there is 80, 8080 and 443.

questions.question_text: A security analyst with an international response team is working to isolate a worldwide distribution of ransomware. The analyst is working with international governing bodies to distribute advanced intrusion detection routines for this variant of ransomware. Which of the following is the MOST important step with which the security analyst should comply?

discussion.content: If you are an analyst working with foreign countries you should definitely comply with export restrictions

comments.content: could be that there are restrictions but i can't imagine that it would be of an analysts concern.... one for the larger team to deal with
Yep, i don't think this question is really meant for cysa

discussion.content: The analyst is working with International bodies and they will distribute advanced intrusion detection routines. Shouldn't be B: Export Restrictions ?

questions.question_text: A worm was detected on multiple PCs within the remote office. The security analyst recommended that the remote office be blocked from the corporate network during the incident response. Which of the following processes BEST describes this recommendation?

discussion.content: I was confused at first why the answer here is 'A - Isolation' and not segmentation. The keyword here is 'blocked from the corporate network'. When we choose segmentation the affected machines maybe segmented to a different subnet or vlan BUT STILL under the same corporate network. So A is correct.

choices.A: Logical isolation of the remote office
